title: Just the usual
quote: For us, there are no good interactions with police.
summary: A semi-final OzTag match turns into another police chase, showing how constant surveillance blocks young people from feeling safe in their own neighbourhood.

title: I can’t even walk down the street
quote: Anytime we’re anywhere we have our escape routes planned in case we need to run.
summary: From childhood, police harassment engrains fear and trauma, pushing kids into fight-or-flight on everyday walks through Mount Druitt.

title: Another overnighter
quote: The police say things to me to get me to bite back at them. Real racist things.
summary: Bail refusals, racist taunts and impossible conditions keep young people trapped in cycles of overnight custody.

title: Here we go again, same shit every day
quote: You shouldn’t have to go into custody to learn about culture, but it’s the only chance you get.
summary: Life on remand is isolating and institutionalising, yet the only consistent access to culture and Elders happens inside detention.

title: Where’s our support?
quote: We need more people who give a fuck and actually ask what we want.
summary: After-hours support is missing, leaving young people without safe spaces, stable housing, or workers who stick around.

title: Taught us how to read and white
quote: If teachers didn’t care enough to try with us, then no one else would.
summary: Racism in classrooms pushes students out, while meaningful cultural learning is the reason they want to stay.

title: Just another way to harass us
quote: They give me another fine to add to my fines; it’s a power trip for them.
summary: Transport checks and relentless fines keep stacking debt that blocks licences, jobs, and a clean slate.

title: Koori Court is probably the best thing I know
quote: In Youth Koori Court they actually see the effort you’re making.
summary: Youth Koori Court centres Elders, culture, and relationships, giving young people a real shot at change.

title: Can’t hold us down
quote: Imagine reconnecting with your blood brothers after being in care for so long, and it’s in jail.
summary: Mounty Yarns grows from lived experience—building community-run solutions that keep families together.
